Name: úttarati

[The assumption by Wackernagel AiGr 1, lii of a sanskritization of MIA. ōtarati (*ottarati) < avatarati to explain late meaning of uttarati ʻ alights, descends ʼ is perh. unnecessary: semant. development was ʻ crosses over -- lands <-> alights (from boat or vehicle) -- descends ʼ: &rcirclemacr 1. Pa. uttarati ʻ crosses over, comes out (of water), boils over ʼ; Pk. uttaraï ʻ goes out, crosses, descends ʼ; P. uttarṇā ʻ to descend, decay ʼ; Ku. utarṇo ʻ to cross (a river), ford, descend ʼ; N. utranu ʻ to descend ʼ; A. utaliba ʻ to be boiled ʼ; B. utarā ʻ to cross, descend ʼ, utulā, ˚lāna ʻ to swell up, boil over ʼ; Or. utaribā ʻ to bubble up, arrive, alight ʼ; OMth. OAw. utaraï ʻ descends ʼ, Bhoj. utaral; H. utarnā ʻ to pass over, encamp, descend ʼ, utrānā intr. ʻ to boil over, foam ʼ; OMarw. utaraï ʻ descends ʼ; G. utarvũ ʻ to cross, descend, decrease ʼ; M. utarṇẽ ʻ to descend, fade ʼ; Si. uturanavā ʻ to overflow, flow out ʼ (pret. utuḷā < *uttr̥ta -- ).

Name: r̥dháti
Description: 2457 r̥dháti (a) ʻ increases, prospers, succeeds ʼ RV. 2. ŕ̊dhyati Dhātup. 3. r̥ddha -- . (b) ʻ *cooks, is cooked ʼ: 1. ŕ̊dhyati. 2. r̥ddha -- . 3. *r̥ndhati (cf. r̥ṇáddhi ʻ increases ʼ RV.) [P. Tedesco BSL 72, 114 (see ND 537 a 34) derives the group ʻ be prosperous or pleased ʼ -- Pk. rijjhaï, riddha -- , &c. -- from an Indo -- ir. *raigh -- in Sogdian rēž ʻ pleasure ʼ. This would however separate Pk. rijjhaï from Pa. ijjhati. The semantic development is ʻ prospers -- is completed -- matures (or is prepared) -- is cooked ʼ: cf. similar development in the poss. connected randháyati. -- √r̥dh]

Name: chárdati
Description: 4998 chárdati Dhātup., chardáyati ʻ causes to flow over ʼ ŚBr., ʻ vomits ʼ MBh. 2. *chr̥ndati, chr̥ṇátti ʻ utters, leaves ʼ TĀr., ʻ vomits ʼ BhP. [Basic meaning is ʻ eject ʼ (cf. MIrish sceirdim ʻ spit out ʼ) seen above and in āˊcchr̥ṇatti ʻ overflows ʼ VS., TS., ŚBr. Semantic development ʻ eject -- leave -- vomit ʼ in both directions is widely paralleled in IA. (ujjhati ʻ emits, leaves ʼ, utkṣipta -- ʻ ejected, dismissed, vomited ʼ, uttarati ʻ comes out, leaves, vomits ʼ, Pa. vihāmi = niṭṭhubhāmi, G. nākhvũ, s.v. naṅkṣyati, ʻ to throw, leave, vomit ʼ; Pa. vanta -- ʻ vomited, renounced ʼ, vāmayati > G. vāmvū̃ ʻ to throw overboard, leave ʼ). NIA. tends to keep MIA. chadd -- (< chárdati) and chaṇḍ -- (< *chr̥ndati) as ʻ vomit ʼ, chaḍḍ -- (< chárdati) as ʻ leave ʼ, but not exclusively. Derivation of Pk. chaḍḍēi < tyakta<-> Tedesco OrLit 1932 col. 527 phonet. impossible and semant. unnecessary. -- √chr̥d]

MBh.; daṁṣṭrikā -- f. ʻ tusk, beard ʼ lex.; dāḍhā -- f. ʻ tusk ʼ lex., dāḍhikā -- f. ʻ beard ʼ Mn., dāḍaka -- m. ʻ tooth ʼ lex. Semant. development ʻ fang -- tusk -- beard ʼ is possible (Rivet BSL 83, 143). But MIA. dāṭhā -- < daṁṣṭrā -- is phonet. difficult. On the other hand *dāṁṣṭra -- (with vr̥ddhi -- formation meaning ʻ pertaining to or collection of fangs ʼ (cf. A. dār below) > ʻ fang ʼ, cf. Wackernagel AiGr ii 2, 130 and 132) would in MIA. become NWPk. *dāṭṭha -- (in S. P. WPah. below), central daṁṭha -- , daṭṭha -- , amg. dāṭha -- , dāḍha -- (with simplification of consonant -- group after orig. IA. long vowel), spread of which at the cost of daṭṭha -- was favoured by clash of the latter with daṭṭha -- < daṣṭa<-> and dr̥ṣṭá -- . Possibility of further Drav. (J. Bloch BSOS v 741) or Mu. (PMWS 63) influence cannot be excluded. -- √daṁś]

Early MIA. *drakṣ -- X prḗkṣatē (Pa. pekkhati, Pk. pecchaï, pēhaï, pekkhaï): ac. to J. Bloch FestschrWackernagel 145 adrēśya -- ʻ invisible ʼ MuṇḍUp. ~ adr̥śya -- reflects invasion of √dr̥ś by this ē (as also in vēkṣaṇa -- Mn. ~ vīˊkṣatē), cf. [Forms of S. with ḍr<-> (and poss. of L. P. with ḍh -- which may however owe their retroflex to anal. pp. ḍhaṭṭha -- ) are prob. < MIA. dhas -- with unexpl. ʻ intrusive ʼ r, rather than < √dhras ʻ glean, throw up ʼ, Pa. dhasati (caus. dhāsēti) ʻ gleans ʼ Saddanīti Dhātumālā 1645. Forms of S. L. P. with ḍr) -- may be due to dissimilation with following -- h<-> (< -- s -- ) or ṭṭh (which replaced tth). In L. P. ḍhah, ḍah, ḍha may be variant spellings for ḍ followed by a vowel with low -- rising -- low tone. L. dassaṇ can be for dhassaṇ after ḍahaṇ; but d -- forms appear also in N. OAw. and H. Are these loans from NW or has another wordgroup (*draśati, *draṣṭa -- , &c.) collided with dhváṁsati &c.? -- √dhvaṁs]

[~ pālá -- , pāráyati1: √pr̥ and &rcirclemacr Pa. Pk. pāra -- n. (Pk. also m.) ʻ further bank ʼ; K. pār m. ʻ further bank ʼ, pôru m. ʻ side ʼ; S. pāru m. ʻ limit, boundary, side ʼ; L. pār m. ʻ bank ʼ; P. pār m. ʻ further bank ʼ; Ku. pār m. ʻ end, limit ʼ; A. pār ʻ river bank, shore, side ʼ; B. pār ʻ opposite side, end, border ʼ, Or. pāra; OMth. pāra ʻ further bank ʼ, H. pār m.; G. pār m. ʻ further bank, end, bottom ʼ; M. pār m. ʻ bank, limit ʼ. -- Adverbial forms: Pa. pāraṁ ʻ beyond ʼ, pāratō ʻ from the other side ʼ; Sh.gil. pār, gur. pari ʻ on the other side ʼ, gil. pāro ʻ from beyond ʼ; K. pāri ʻ from ʼ; S. pāri ʻ on the opposite side, across, through ʼ, pārõ ʻ from the opposite side ʼ; L. pāre) ʻ beyond ʼ, pārõ ʻ from beyond ʼ, pārũ ʻ by means of ʼ, awāṇ. pār ʻ across ʼ; P. pāre) ʻ beyond ʼ, WPah. all dial. pār; Ku. par ʻ at a distance, aside ʼ, gng. pār ʻ beyond ʼ; N. pāri ʻ beyond ʼ, pār postp. w. obl. ʻ on the other side of ʼ, para ʻ aside ʼ; B. Mth. H. pār ʻ on the other side of, across ʼ, OAw. pāra; G. pāri ʻ beyond ʼ, M. pār. -- (With emphatic aspiration?) Kho. phar ʻ on the further side, far away, across ʼ; Phal. phār) ʻ across ʼ, pharaṛo pron. ʻ that (in front) ʼ, ˚ṛā ʻ there ʼ; -- cf. Tor. phēm s.v. *pārima -- . <-> Paš.weg. pārē, ar. pṓru, phōrūˊ, kuṛ. phāˊrau ʻ the day after tomorrow ʼ (IIFL iii 3, 145) rather < paraśvas?

[The theory (EWA ii 221 with lit.) that parkaṭī -- is sanskritization of a MIA. *pakkha -- ḍa -- < prakṣá -- would unite all the NIA. words, but does not account for the absence of aspiration in B. Or. Bhoj. H. M. On the other hand parka -- ṭī<-> is poss. a genuine ablaut variant: IE. *perkṷ -- u -- in *parku -- ṭī -- (replaced by parkaṭī -- with commoner ending?), Lat. quercus ʻ oak ʼ: *prekṷ -- s -- in prakṣá -- : *pr̥kṷ -- in OHG. forha ʻ pine ʼ IEW 822 (J. C. W.). In this case the aspiration of the H. P. M. words < parkaṭī<-> might be due to collision with *pakkha -- < prakṣá -- ]

Name: phirati

Poss. phar -- and phir -- are MIA. < *spar -- , *spir -- and belong to √spr̥ for which the basic meaning ʻ convey ʼ (~ √pr̥) would account for the uses ʻ rescue (from: abl.) ʼ, ʻ help (towards: dat.) ʼ, ʻ attain, win ʼ (cf. *sparati). With this Ir. *spar -- (usu. attributed to Sk. sphuráti: Bartholomae AirWb 1613 for Av. spar -- ʻ tread, hasten ʼ, Horn NPE 155) may be cognate in some of its meanings, e.g. Pers. sipardan ʻ to travel ʼ (J. C. W.)]

Name: baṭu

[PMWS 99 of Mu. origin: prob. one of a group of ʻ defective ʼ words, cf. *baḍu -- s.v. baṇḍá -- and *bēṭṭa -- . <-> There appears to be a base bā̆ -- in both IE. and nonAryan ʻ defective ʼ and ʻ nursery ʼ words and interjections: cf. batá -- ʻ wretch ʼ RV., bālá -- ʻ fool, child ʼ, balā -- ʻ youngest sister ʼ lex., *bā -- , Lat. bārō ʻ fool ʼ; bata, báṭ, baḷāˊ RV., bāˊl AV., Av. bā, bāda interjections. Name: bhaginī
Description: 9349 bhaginī f. ʻ sister ʼ Mn., ˚nikā -- f. Kathās. [J. Gonda AO xxi 23 supports derivation from bhaga -- 2 ʻ vulva ʼ (which, if it belongs to the ʻ crooked ʼ or ʻ defective ʼ word -- groups of bhaṅgurá -- or *vaṅka -- 2, might with a variant *bagha -- account for *baghinī -- ~ bhaginī -- ). But EWA ii 460 sees in it more prob. the feminine of bhagín -- as an expression of good wish -- bhágaḥ kanīˊnām of RV. i 163, 8 -- to an unwed sister (note that in NIA. bhaginī -- is usu. the younger sister). The transference of aspiration from the initial to the interior presents difficulty, unless as a conscious avoidance of similarity with bhaga -- 2 ʻ vulva ʼ. The argument in AO xxi 30 that no *baghinī -- is attested and that therefore the transference could have occurred only at the stage bhaïṇī<-> is not conclusive that a form *baghinī -- never in fact existed between the age of Aśoka and the first emergence of Pk. bahiṇī -- . It is significant that in bhāginēya -- no such transference occurred. The new bahiṇī -- belonged to the Centre, the older bhaïṇī -- remaining on the periphery in Dard., S., L., P., some WH. dialects, EA., Or., and Ko. -- For distribution of svásr̥ -- and bhaginī -- in NIA. see AO xxi 27. -- bhagín -- ]

Mng. ʻ breakable ʼ from association with bhaṅga -- 1. Also bhaga -- 2 ʻ vulva ʼ (with poss. variation *bagha -- , see bhaginī -- ) may belong here, either as ʻ bend, curve ʼ or as general ʻ defective ʼ word, such as in so many cases provides sexual terms]

Bloch BSL xxxi 62, despite bhanakti ʻ puts to flight ʼ MW. and Pk. bhaṁjāvia -- ʻ put to flight ʼ, dissociates NIA. words meaning ʻ flee ʼ from √bhañj and associates with IE. *bhegw -- (Gk. fe/bomai ʻ I flee ʼ, &c., IEW 116) in (diśō)' bhājayat ʻ drove out ʼ (see 3 below), (diśō) 'bhyabhajatām ʻ fled ʼ Bhaṭṭ., diśōbhāga -- ʻ fleeing ʼ Pañcat. But in view of parallel semantic development of dīryátē, dīrṇá -- , it is not necessary to assume a separate *bhajyati ʻ flees ʼ, pp. *bhagna -- 2 which in any case would have coalesced completely with bhajyátē, bhagna -- 1 from √bhañj]

But other agencies may have been at work: taboo, as with ʻ spleen ʼ and ʻ liver ʼ, or contamination with other words, such as mḗdas -- ~ bhejj -- , N. mās (< māṁsá -- ) ~ māsi?]

Apte, bahēṭaka -- m. lex. [vibhīˊdaka<-> was affected by the names of the other two constituents of the triphala -- , viz. harītaka -- and āmalaka -- : thus vibhīˊtaka -- after the former (in its turn replaced by harīṭaka -- after vibhīṭaka -- ), while after the second vibhēdaka -- or *vibhēḍaka -- was replaced by *vibhēlaka<-> (or MIA. -- l -- < -- ḍ -- ). Initial v -- was assimilated to b<-> by the following -- bh -- (cf. a similar assimilation in vihvala -- ) and so appears in Pk. and all NIA. forms except M. -- MIA. *vihīaa -- → Pers. bih ʻ quince ʼ Laufer 584, whence back → NIA.: K. bih ʻ quince ʼ, S. behī f., H. bihī f.]

Name: sájati
Description: 13085 sájati ʻ is attached, embraces ʼ Dhātup. (ásakta aor. ʻ adhered to ʼ TBr., āˊsajāmi ʻ place in ʼ RV.). 2. *sājayati. 3. sañjayati ʻ attaches to ʼ Bhag., ʻ couples ʼ Mn. 4. sajyátē (sajjatē MBh.) intr. ʻ hangs on ʼ ŚBr., ʻ is occupied with ʼ MBh. 5. saktá -- ʻ clinging to ʼ AV. [Kaf. Dard. K. and WPah. presuppose MIA. *ṣā̆y) -- , *ṣajj -- (*ṣacc -- ), *ṣatta -- . These may derive from √sañj with ṣ -- replacing s -- in the simplex after cmpds. with ati (AV.), vyati (TBr.), anu (ŚBr.), abhi (MBh.), ni (RV.), pari (MBh.), prati, vi (TS.), adhivi (MBh.), abhivi (BhP.). Dhp. has &gacute -- ~ saṅgá -- Brough Dhp 101. Cf. similar replacement of dental by retroflex in √sthā, √stambh. T. Burrow's (BSOAS xii 650) assumption of a √*sraj ~ √*sañj is unlikely and unnecessary. All NIA. words under 1 and 2 (except Kho. šoyek in which š -- can derive only from ś -- or ṣ -- , since śr -- is preserved) phonet. and semant. equally well (1) < śráyati in Si. sayanavā, (2) < śrāyayati (IIFL iii 3, 170, Buddruss Woṭ 125, Burrow KharDoc 14). But this would not account for their association with intr. or pass. stem *ṣajj -- or *ṣacc -- , and pp. and pret. *ṣatta -- . Possibly śráyati and *ṣajati coalesced in NIA. as a pres. st. for which only *ṣajj -- (replaced anal. by *ṣacc -- ) and *ṣatta -- served as pass. -- intr. and pp. Thus Paš.chil. ṣītik ʻ it has stuck ʼ may be *ṣia -- < śritá -- X *ṣatta -- . -- √sañj]

Name: síkatā
Description: 13386 síkatā f. ʻ grain of sand ʼ, (usu. pl.) ʻ sand, gravel ʼ VS., sigatā -- f. Kap. [Collective formation from sika -- in śvēta -- sika -- druka -- ʻ scattering white sand ʼ TĀr. 1. 12. 3 A. Sharma in Bhārata -- kaumudī 873. Kaf. and some Dard. forms attest IA. ś -- corresponding to Ir. q -- and s -- (OPers. qikā -- , Bal. six, Psht. šəga, &c. EVP 73) and support E. Benveniste BSL xxx 60 in assumption that s -- forms of Sk. and other Dard. languages and WPah. (which distinguish ś and s) are loans from or influenced by Iranian. Variations in Kaf. and Dard. of -- g -- ~ -- k<-> and -- l -- ~ -- t -- may be due to borrowings within that group or to later Ir. influences or they may, in part at least, be due to suffix. variation like that of síkatā -- ~ *sikatī -- (in sikatyà -- VS.) ~ siktā -- lex. ~ *sikyā -- ]

Poss. also > MIA. (NW?) *cāṅgh -- , *cāggh -- (→ EAś. cagh -- , B. cāgā s.v. *caghyati) J. C. W. -- But (1) date of Aś. is early for change ṅgh > ggh and for spread of these forms to East; (2) S. caghu (with a) would imply early borrowing from E or S unless a separate *caṅkṣ<-> ~ *cāṅkṣ -- (necessary for *cāh -- ) is assumed.

Name: práṇīta

Name: plúṣi
Description: 14711 plúṣi [All forms with initial pr -- , ṭḷ -- , pl -- , l -- , p -- are prob. < early MIA. pr -- < OIA. pl -- . In Sh. (in which OIA. pr -- > c̣ -- ), since in all other lggs. this MIA. pr -- < pl -- merges with OIA. pr -- , prī˜ẓu is prob. ← Phal. prī˜ṣu rather than that pl -- > pr -- after the change of OIA. pr -- towards c̣ -- . -- Similarly in all MIA. (incl. late Sk., e.g. Dhātup.) and NIA. words with pr -- or p -- (~ pil -- ) < OIA. pl -- : see plakṣá -- (prakṣá -- ), plīhán -- , √plu, √pluṣ (√pruṣ2), plōta -- . -- The same development occurred in OIA. ml -- > (mbr -- : see mlḗcchati; and in OIA. kl -- > kr -- (which outside NW > k -- ) or kil -- : see *klava -- , klānta -- , *klāvyatē, √klid, √kliś (√*kriś), klṓman -- . -- Similarly with voiced initials: gl -- > gr -- (~ gil -- ) in glāní -- and vl -- > vr/br -- in vlēpita -- . -- It is to be noted that in all these words (except vlēpita -- with only an Ir. congener and the etym. obscure plakṣá -- ) l corresponds with an IE. l. <-> Similar development in K. śr -- < śl -- (śrônu < ślakṣṇa -- )]

Name: phalph

W.)]

P. rāṭh m. ʻ cruel hard -- hearted man ʼ poss. < *rāṣṭr̥ -- (~ Ved. rāˊṣṭrī -- ) early replaced by rāṣṭríya -- (~ kṣatríya -- ) ʻ pretender ʼ MaitrS., ʻ king's brother -- in -- law (in drama with connotations of rāṭh in L. Name: śálka

Name: śuṇḍā-
Description: 14817 śuṇḍā -- 1: Tir. šuṇḍ ← Psht.? (G.M.).

Name: śuna
Description: 14818 śuna -- : Paš.lauṛ. šunǰ f. ʻ bitch ʼ < *śunacī -- ? (G.M.).

Name: śubhāná
Description: 14819 śubhāná -- : L. savāṇī rather < *sujāni -- ?

Name: śōṇita
Description: 14820 śōṇita [śōṇa -- n. ʻ blood ʼ lex. → Orm. šun ʻ blood ʼ IIFL i 408]

Name: śōdhya
Description: 14821 śōdhya -- : M. sojī rather < *sōjja -- .

Name: śṓśucat
Description: 14822 śṓśucat -- : Kal.rumb. šišṓyak ʻ beautiful ʼ, Phal. šišówo: or < *suśōbha -- ?

Name: śrāva
Description: 14823 śrāva -- : Ash. Wg. Pr. (Buddruss) c̣ā ʻ voice, cry, call ʼ (Ash. c̣ā lā -- ʻ to call ʼ, Pr. c̣ā li -- ʻ to call out ʼ, Wg. c̣ā křõi ʻ called out ʼ were wrongly analysed s.v. caláyati).

Name: śrī́
Description: 14824 śrīˊ -- : M. -- s affix to names of relationship rather < svāmin -- , cf. use of -- bhaṭṭa -- with names in śrīmhāla -- bh˚ = mhālasā -- bh˚ in 16th cent. Sk. (J. C. W.).

Name: śrēṣman
Description: 14825 *śrēṣman -- : for B. chep, Or. chepa in view of frequent B. Or. ch -- ~ ś -- contamination with *cippa -- is unlikely.

Name: ślakṣṇá
Description: 14826 ślakṣṇá -- : Paš. (Leech) "sanna" ʻ thin ʼ, dar. sánɔ -- gēn, weg. sanā -- gēnī (gēnī) < gavīnīˊ -- ) rather ← Ind. than with IIFL iii 3, 158 < sáṁnata -- .

Name: ślā́ghatē
Description:
14827 ślāˊghatē: Gy. wel. šār -- ʻ to praise, celebrate ʼ (or < uccārayati)

Name: śvāsá
Description: 14828 śvāsá [Psht. sāh ʻ breath ʼ ← IA. EVP 66]

Name: saṁcŕ̊t
Description: 14829 saṁcŕ̊t -- : but cf. also Kho. (← Yid.) sanǰ ʻ floor plank ʼ, Ishk. ṣanǰ, Shgh. sānǰ of unknown origin (G.M.).

Name: sáṁnata
Description: 14830 sáṁnata -- : Paš. words (like she. sanāˊ) rather ← Ind. < ślakṣṇá -- (G.M.).

Name: saṁnaṣṭa
Description: 14831 saṁnaṣṭa -- : H. sannāṭā (→ N. sannāṭo) m. ʻ desolate silence, fearstrickenness ʼ prob. same as sannāṭā m. ʻ loud whistling or whizzing noise ʼ s.v. saṁnādayati and conn. with san -- in the reduplicated formations sansanānā ʻ to whizz, whistle ʼ (s.v. svaná -- ) and sansanī f. ʻ silence, fearstrickenness ʼ with the same range of meaning (J. C. W.).

Name: saṁsthita
Description: 14832 saṁsthita -- : Gy. eur. stil -- ʻ to arrest, apprehend ʼ (GWZS 3178)?

Name: sarga
Description: 14833 sarga -- : K. sagun (caus. sagawun, sagarun) ʻ to irrigate, water, sprinkle water on ʼ rather < MIA. *sagga -- pp. to pres. st. sajj -- (aor. pass. asarji RV., caus. sarjayati, Pa. sajjēti ~ sr̥játi, ˚tē ʻ lets water flow ʼ RV., Pa. sajati ʻ lets loose ʼ, Pk. sayaï ʻ drips, flows ʼ) after type bhajjaï ~ bhagga -- .

Name: sarjayati
Description: 14834 sarjayati: for forms in K. see sarga -- Add. -- Si. sadanavā, ha˚ prob. < sajjayati.

Name: sāmānya
Description: 14835 sāmānya -- : Ku. swānī, swāniko der. *swān rather than < *sāmāniya -- .

Name: siddha-
Description: 14836 siddha -- 2: Gy. eur. sido ʻ fine, smooth, thin ʼ GWZS 2894.

Name: saindhavá
Description: 14837 saindhavá -- : Gy. eur. sendo, sindo (usu. pl. ˚de) m. ʻ a Gypsy ʼ (GWZS 2916)?

Name: snāna
Description: 14838 snāna -- : Gy. rum. hung. nan -- d -- ʻ to bathe ʼ Miklosich Mund viii 22.

Name: snāpáyati
Description: 14839 snāpáyati: Gy. rum. nayuvav ʻ I bathe myself ʼ, pret. nail'óm Miklosich Mund viii 22.

Name: sníh
Description: 14840 sníh -- : Sh. hĭn &c. ʻ snow ʼ, Sv. hina altern. < *himna -- ?

Name: sraṁs
Description: 14841 SRAṀS v.l. śraṁs, but hras -- in Av. frahrasyan- ʻ name of a subterranean being ʼ (J. C. W.).

Name: haḍḍa
Description: 14842 haḍḍa -- : Gy. eur. hero m. ʻ bone, thigh ʼ (GWZS 1063) with unexpl. e.

Name: hárati
Description: 14843 hárati: Paš. ar -- ʻ to accept, agree, hear ʼ rather (like ār -- ʻ to bring ʼ) < āˊharati.

Name: hásta
Description: 14844 hásta -- : Wg. (Gambir) dōš ʻ hand and forearm ʼ, doš- &atildedotdot ʻ palm of hand ʼ.

Name: himna
Description:
14845 *himna -- : Sh.gil. hĭn m., gur. koh. hinn f., jij. hĭ̄n ʻ snow ʼ, Sv. hina rather than < sníh -- ?
